title: Abbreviations
description: Learn the proper use of abbreviations in Canadian government writing

content.text: The use of abbreviations has gained greater acceptance as an increasing number of new products and organizations are identified by shorter and more easily recognizable word forms. In addition to abbreviations in the strict sense (including the short forms of common nouns, Latin expressions and titles), this chapter contains information and recommendations regarding acronyms, initialisms, and symbols such as those for metric units, which are uniform in many languages.
Many abbreviations will not be understood unless the term is written in full at first mention, with the abbreviation given in parentheses.

keyPrinciple.title: Key Principle
keyPrinciple.content: Use abbreviations sparingly in formal writing. When in doubt, spell it out completely.

rules: In general, abbreviate words only when the short form will be immediately recognized by the reader, and ensure that the same abbreviation is used elsewhere in your text to represent the word or words involved.
Some standard abbreviations such as i.e., AD, IQ, ESR, CBC and MP do not have to be spelled out because they are well known and in many cases occur as dictionary entries.

Many commonly used words that are actually abbreviations are now rarely regarded as such, including ad, fridge, phone, exam, memo, photo and math. Most such words should be avoided in formal writing, although cello and bus are exceptions to this rule.

examples.text: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) announced new programming. The CBC will focus on...
The CBC announced new programming. (Without first defining it)

content.text: The use of periods in abbreviations follows specific rules:
rules: Use periods with most abbreviations (Mr., Dr., etc., i.e., Ph.D.)
Do not use periods with SI/metric symbols (km, kg, L) except at the end of a sentence
Do not use periods with acronyms and initialisms that are pronounced as words (NATO, radar, UNESCO)
Use periods with initialisms that are pronounced letter by letter (U.S.A., B.C., P.E.I.)

examples.text: The box weighs 5 kg. (when not at end of sentence)

content.text: Form plurals of abbreviations according to these guidelines:
rules: Add 's' (no apostrophe) for most abbreviations: MPs, CEOs, PhDs
Some abbreviations have special plural forms: Mr. → Messrs., Mrs. → Mmes., p. → pp., Ms. → Mses. (rarely used)

warningBox.title: SI/Metric Symbols
warningBox.content: SI/metric symbols maintain the same form for both singular and plural and are written without periods, except at the end of a sentence: 5 cm (NOT 5 cms), The boxer weighed only 75 kg.

content.text: In general, an abbreviation is capitalized or hyphenated if the unabbreviated word or words are so treated.

examples.text: MLA → Member of the Legislative Assembly

specialRule.title: Special Capitalization Rule
specialRule.content: When an abbreviation is formed from letters most or all of which are part of a single word, it is capitalized, even though the full term is not:

content.text: Use the following abbreviations for non-military titles preceding or following personal names:

keyPrinciple.title: Usage of Ms.
keyPrinciple.content: Use Ms. when referring to a woman unless a preference for Mrs. has been indicated. Although not an abbreviation, Ms. is written with a period, by analogy with Mr. and Mrs. Note that Miss is not an abbreviation and does not take a period.

warningBox.title: Important Rule
warningBox.content: Do not use Mr., Mrs., Ms., Dr. or Esq. with any other abbreviated title or with an abbreviation for an academic degree.

examples.text: Dr. John Smith OR John Smith, Ph.D.
Mr. William Jones OR William Jones, Esq.

content.text: Military ranks and titles follow specific abbreviation conventions. Abbreviate military ranks only when they precede a personal name.
content.note: In formal military documents, consult the appropriate military style guide for complete lists and usage rules.

sections.title: University Degrees, Professional Designations, Military Decorations, Honours, Awards and Memberships

content.text: Abbreviations for degrees, honours and professional designations follow the person's name and are set off by commas.

orderOfPrecedence.title: Order of Precedence
orderOfPrecedence.content: When multiple abbreviations follow a name, use this order:

examples.text: Jane Smith, Ph.D., will lead the research.
Dr. Jane Smith will lead the research.
Dr. Jane Smith, Ph.D., will lead the research.

content.text: Abbreviate geographical terms according to these guidelines:
rules: Generally spell out names of countries, provinces, and territories in text
Abbreviate in addresses, lists, and when space is limited
Use standard postal abbreviations for provinces and territories

keyPrinciple.title: In Formal Text
keyPrinciple.content: Spell out province and territory names in formal documents and running text. Use abbreviations primarily in addresses and tables.

sections.title: Addresses: Streets and Buildings; Points of the Compass

content.text: Guidelines for abbreviating address components:
rules: Abbreviate street designations in addresses but spell out in running text
Abbreviate compass points when they follow a street name
Do not abbreviate when compass points are part of a place name (North York, West Vancouver)

examples.text: The office is on Main Street. (in running text)

content.text: Express latitude and longitude using degree symbols and standard abbreviations.
content.format: Use the degree symbol (°) followed by the direction without a space: 45°N, 75°W

sections.title: Parts of a Book or Document

content.text: Common abbreviations for parts of books and documents:
Common Latin abbreviations used in English writing:

abbreviations.usage: Use in parenthetical material; spell out 'for example' in main text
Use in parenthetical material; spell out 'that is' in main text
Acceptable in all contexts, but avoid overuse
Used in citations with multiple authors

warningBox.title: Avoid Overuse
warningBox.content: In formal writing, prefer English equivalents. Reserve Latin abbreviations for parenthetical material and scholarly contexts.

content.text: Abbreviations for scientific and technical terms should be used carefully and defined on first use unless universally known.
rules: Define technical abbreviations on first use
Use standard scientific notation and symbols
Be consistent throughout the document
Consult field-specific style guides when in doubt

content.text: Guidelines for abbreviating business and organization names:
rules: Use the organization's preferred abbreviation or acronym
Define acronyms on first use unless extremely well known
Respect the organization's capitalization and spacing preferences

examples.text: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) will air the documentary. CBC representatives confirmed...
Smith & Sons Ltd. announced new products.

content.note: Always check the company's official name for correct abbreviation style.

content.text: Understanding the difference and proper usage:

definitions.definition: An abbreviation pronounced as a word (e.g., NATO, radar, scuba, UNESCO)
An abbreviation pronounced letter by letter (e.g., FBI, CBC, HTML, RCMP)

capitalizationRules: Acronyms of five letters or fewer: usually all capitals (NATO, RCMP)
Acronyms of six letters or more: may be written with initial capital only (Unicef, Unesco) when well established
Initialisms: always all capitals (CBC, UN, MP, HRDC)

keyPrinciple.title: First Use Rule
keyPrinciple.content: Always provide the full term on first use, followed by the acronym/initialism in parentheses, unless the abbreviation is more familiar than the full form.

exceptions: Very well-known acronyms (NATO, UN, FBI) may not need definition
Common technology terms (DVD, USB, CD) are often used without definition
When using SIN (social insurance number), PIN (personal identification number) or ISBN, do not repeat the word 'number' (e.g., avoid 'SIN number')

examples.text: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) held a summit. NATO members agreed...
Insert the USB drive. (No definition needed - universally known)

content.text: Guidelines for using number signs and percentage symbols:

numberSymbol.usage: When abbreviating the words number or numbers within the body of a text, use No. or Nos. but not the symbol #, which is generally reserved for tabular and statistical material.

percentSymbol.usage: Use the percent sign (%) in economic, financial, statistical or other documents where figures are abundant. In material of a general nature containing isolated references to percentages, the term is usually written out, except when used adjectivally.

examples.text: a 15% bond (no space between numeral and %)

content.text: The ampersand (&) is properly used only when it forms part of a corporate name.
rules: Use the ampersand ONLY in official business names where it appears
Do NOT use the ampersand in federal department legal or applied titles
Spell out 'and' in all other contexts

examples.text: The case is being defended by Collins, Smith, White & Jones.
The Department of Public Works & Government Services
The Department of Public Works and Government Services
The Department of Indian Affairs & Northern Development
The Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development

warningBox.title: Important Rule
warningBox.content: Do NOT use the ampersand in federal department names. Write 'Public Works and Government Services.' Use & only when it's part of an official corporate name (e.g., AT&T, Smith & Jones).

content.text: When it is necessary to distinguish dollar amounts in one currency from those in another, use the appropriate symbol with the figure in question.

examples.text: The loan will be repaid in eighty instalments of C$650 (or CAN$650) each.
Please enclose a cheque in the amount of US$100.

content.note: See sections 5.11 and 5.26 for further information on monetary units.

content.text: Always spell out the names of the months in the body of your text and in footnotes. They may be abbreviated in tabular matter, citations and references, forms and sidenotes.
rules: Always spell out month names in body text and footnotes
May be abbreviated in tables, citations, forms and sidenotes
May should NEVER be abbreviated
June and July are shortened only in military writing
Days of the week are not abbreviated, except in tables

examples.text: The meeting is scheduled for March 15, 2024. (body text)

sections.title: Time of Day and Elapsed Time

content.text: Present exact time and elapsed time according to these formats:

timeOfDay.title: Time of Day
timeOfDay.note: Use lowercase letters with periods for a.m. and p.m.

elapsedTime.title: Elapsed Time
elapsedTime.format: Use colons, periods and no spaces: 2:30:21.65 (hours, minutes, seconds, tenths, hundredths)

content.note: See sections 5.12 and 5.13 for additional information on time representation.

content.text: Time zones are abbreviated when used with a specific time. Note that capitals are used, without periods. Otherwise they are written out in full.

examples.text: Pacific standard time (when not used with a specific time)
daylight saving time (when not used with a specific time)

keyPrinciple.title: Capitalization Rule
keyPrinciple.content: Use all capitals without periods when abbreviating time zones with a specific time. Write out in full (lowercase) when used generally.

content.text: The International System of Units (SI), which has replaced other metric systems and is now used in Canada and many other countries, is a decimal-based system that includes units for physical quantities.

derivedUnits.note: Like the kelvin and the ampere, almost all derived units are named after scientists associated with a scientific discovery. Thus, when the symbol is used, its initial letter is capitalized. When written in full, however, the unit name is in lower case, e.g. H for henry and F for farad.
derivedUnits.exception: Celsius takes an initial capital whether written in full or as a symbol.

criticalRules: SI symbols are not abbreviations and are never followed by periods (except at end of sentence)
SI symbols never take a plural 's'
Leave a space between the numeral and the symbol: 5 kg, 10 m, 25 °C
When a unit symbol is combined with time or division, use an oblique (/): 80 km/h, 1800 r/min, 50 A/m
Area and volume use superscript numerals: 5 cm³, 20 m²
Write both numerals and unit names in full OR both abbreviated: two metres or 2 m
incorrectAbbreviations: Do NOT use: cc or cu. cm for cubic centimetre (correct: cm³)
Do NOT use: kilo for kilogram (correct: kg)
Do NOT use: amp for ampere (correct: A)
Do NOT use: kph for kilometres per hour (correct: km/h)

examples.text: The box measures 5 cm by 10 cm.
5 kg. (period only at end of sentence)

content.note: There is no standard symbol for week or month. These units should therefore always be spelled out in technical writing.

content.text: Abbreviations for imperial weights and measures take the same form for singular and plural. Area and volume in this system are usually expressed by means of the abbreviations sq. and cu. rather than a superscript numeral.
rules: Abbreviations are the same for singular and plural
Use sq. and cu. for area and volume (not superscripts)
Leave a space between sq. or cu. and the following abbreviation

content.text: Terms are often abbreviated for the purpose of conserving space in routine business correspondence. The following are common abbreviations used in tables and on business forms:
spacingRules: A space is usually required before and after the symbols @, =, and ×
No extra space is required for upper-case abbreviations or in e-mail addresses: R&D at AT&T, sales@wordlink.ca
No space is required between figures and the symbols % and #: 10% deficit, nearly 75¢ a pound, 43# per bag
Do not leave any space after the symbols $, #, ¶, § when they precede a figure: less than $278, package #3412, Refer to §1.28
content.note: These abbreviations are appropriate for tables and forms but should generally be avoided in formal business letters. In formal correspondence, spell out terms completely.
